details.purpose: To record summary details about a single poisoning event.
details.use:
Use to record summary details about a single poisoning event.
Use cases include, but are not limited to: - public health surveillance about poisoning events.
details.misuse: Not to be used to record summary information about a broader pattern of exposure to a substance. Use the EVALUATION.exposure_summary for this purpose.
details.copyright: Â© openEHR Foundation, Ministry of Health and Wellness Jamaica

items.items: Summary details about a single poisoning event, including accidental exposure to a substance at home, in the workplace, or within the broader community or environment, as well as deliberate self-poisoning.
Name of the substance or agent causally linked with the poisoning.
The physical form or presentation of the substance at the time of exposure.
The state of the substance or agent may be different in its' stored form, for example a liquid that is inhaled as a gas.
Category of packaging for the substance.
The route of exposure for the affected individual.
The amount, or estimate of the amount, of substance ingested, inhaled or absorbed by the individual.
Narrative or category of the physical location where the poisoning event took place.
Home of the poisoned individual or another person.
Educational institution, such as a school, kindergarten, or university.
Place of employment where the individual was working or present in a professional capacity.
Specific details about the organisation or physical address where the poisoning event took place.
Narrative or category describing of the physical or environmental context where the poisoning event occurred.
For example: well ventilated or enclosed space; indoors or outdoors.
Additional information required to extend the model with local content or to align with other reference models or formalisms.
For example: local information requirements; or additional metadata to align with FHIR.
Narrative description about the poisoning event.
The date and optional time of exposure to the substance or, for exposures extending over a period, the start of the exposure.
Date and time when the individual first attended a medical service after exposure.
More than one occurrence to record date/time for each level of medical service provided.
The type of occurrence of the poisoning event.
For example: first event or subsequent episode of poisoning
The event is the first ever exposure for the individual.
The event is a second or subsequent exposure for the individual.
The sequence number of this event within a series of related poisoning events.
Date/time this poisoning event summary was last updated.
Substance was stored in the manufacturer's original packaging and container.
Substance was not stored in the manufacturer's original packaging or container.
Narrative description about the packaging of the substance.
For example: if the substance was labelled or packaged inappropriately.
The colour of the substance at the time of exposure.
Narrative or category describing the occupational context of the poisoning event.
Identification of a risk factor that contributed to the occurrence of the poisoning event.
This data element has multiple occurrences to allow more than one risk factor to be recorded. Coding with an external terminology is recommended, if available.
Another site other than residential, educational or workplace.
Substance flows to take the shape of its container; exposure by ingestion, dermal absorption, or accidental splashes.
Substance exists in a gaseous state, often invisible; exposure primarily by inhalation.
Substance is a suspension of fine particles or liquid droplets dispersed in a gas.
Substance is a fixed shape and volume; exposure by ingestion, inhalation as a dust or skin absorption.
Specific type of solid form or presentation of the substance at the time of exposure.
A solid dosage form of a substance, often compacted into a small, flat, or slightly rounded shape for oral administration.
A solid dosage form consisting of a substance enclosed within a soluble gelatin or similar shell for oral consumption.
A small, solid, rounded or cylindrical mass of a substance, typically used for controlled release or specific applications (e.g., pesticide pellets).
A large, solid mass of a substance, typically uniform in shape, used in bulk applications (e.g., rat poison blocks).
A finely ground, loose, dry substance consisting of small particles (e.g., talcum powder, powdered drugs).
Small, irregularly shaped particles larger than powder but smaller than pellets (e.g., granular fertilizers or detergents).
Solid substances with a defined geometric shape and internal structure due to their molecular arrangement (e.g., salt crystals, methamphetamine).
Sharp, irregular fragments of a brittle solid.
Thin, flat pieces of a substance, often irregularly shaped (e.g., paint flakes, graphite flakes).
Thin, thread-like structures that may be woven or used individually (e.g., fiberglass, asbestos fibers).
Specific type of liquid form or presentation of the substance at the time of exposure.
Homogeneous mixtures where the poison is fully dissolved in a solvent, such as water or alcohol. For example: antifreeze (ethylene glycol) and certain cleaning agents.
Heterogeneous mixtures containing solid particles dispersed in a liquid medium. For example, liquid pesticides with suspended active ingredients.
Mixtures of two immiscible liquids where one is dispersed in the other, often stabilized by emulsifiers. For example: medicinal creams and lotions.
Semi-solid systems where a liquid is entrapped within a three-dimensional polymeric network, giving a jelly-like consistency. For example, hand sanitizers and certain topical medications.
Irregular, larger solid pieces, not uniform in shape or size (e.g., broken pieces of solid chemicals).
Small, spherical particles, often uniform in size, used in industrial or pharmaceutical applications (e.g., silica gel beads, bead-based medications).
Fine, dry particulate matter suspended in air or settled on surface.
Colloidal systems where gas bubbles are dispersed in a liquid matrix. For example, some cleaning agents and cosmetic products.
The exposure occurred in an occupational context.
The exposure did not occur in an occupational context.
Additional narrative about the poisoning event not captured in other fields.
Narrative or category describing the safety context of the poisoning event.
